originalTitle: South Africa and Israel expel each other's envoys in diplomatic row
title: A Friendly Chat: Countries Having a Big Disagreement!
content:
Hello, Super Friends!

Hi everyone! It's your friend here, bringing you super important news from our amazing continent, Africa, and beyond! Today, we're talking about something that happened between two countries: South Africa and a country called Israel. It's a bit like when two friends have a misunderstanding, but much bigger! Let's find out what happened together, in a very simple way.

What's Going On?

So, imagine you have a very special messenger. This messenger goes from your house to your friend's house. That's a bit like an "envoy" for a country! South Africa and Israel had special messengers, called envoys, who usually help them talk to each other. But lately, these countries have had a big disagreement. It made them both ask the other country's messenger to leave. This is called "expelling" them.

Meet South Africa!

First, let's talk about our wonderful South Africa! It's a big, beautiful country right here in Africa, at the very bottom tip. It's famous for its amazing wildlife like lions, elephants, and rhinos! It also has beautiful beaches and mountains. Lots of different people live there, speaking many different languages. It's known as the "Rainbow Nation" because everyone lives together like many colours in a rainbow! Did you know? South Africa has 11 official languages! That's a lot of ways to say hello!

Meet Our President!

Every country has a leader, just like your school has a principal. In South Africa, the leader is called the President. Our President's name is President Ramaphosa. He is very important for South Africa. He works hard to make sure everyone in South Africa is safe and happy. He helps make big decisions for the country.

What's an "Envoy"?

Now, let's talk about that word, "envoy." It might sound tricky, but it's really simple! An envoy is like a special friend or a representative. They are sent by their country to another country. Their job is to talk to the leaders there. They help the two countries understand each other. They share messages and try to keep things friendly. Think of it like this: If your family visits another family, you send a message ahead of time. Or you send a thank you note afterwards. The envoy helps with all these important talks between countries. They are there to build bridges, not walls!

A Big Disagreement

So, what made the two countries unhappy? South Africa said that Israel's envoy said something not nice about President Ramaphosa. Saying something bad about a country's leader is a very serious thing. It can hurt feelings. It can make people upset. It's like someone saying mean things about your mom or dad. That would make you sad and angry, right? South Africa felt that the Israeli envoy was disrespectful. They felt it was not a friendly thing to do. They felt it was wrong for the special messenger to say bad things about their President. Did you know? Countries usually try very hard to be polite to each other. It helps them work together on important things like peace and helping people.

What Does "Expel" Mean?

Because South Africa was so unhappy, they decided to "expel" the Israeli envoy. What does "expel" mean? It means to ask someone to leave. It means to say, "Please go back to your country." It's like if you had a friend visiting your home, and they said something very rude to your parents. Your parents might politely ask them to go home. That's what South Africa did. It's a very big deal when a country expels an envoy. It means the friendship between the two countries is in trouble. It means they are not getting along very well right now.

Israel's Side of the Story

But what did Israel say about this? Israel said that South Africa's decision was "baseless." That means Israel thinks South Africa's reason to expel their envoy was not fair. Israel believes their envoy did nothing wrong. They think there was no good reason to ask their special messenger to leave. So, Israel was also unhappy. Because Israel felt it was unfair, they also decided to expel South Africa's envoy! It was like saying, "If you send our friend home, we will send your friend home too!" It's a tricky situation when both sides feel they are right. Did you know? When countries expel each other's envoys, it means they might stop talking directly for a while. This can make it harder to solve problems.

Why is This Important?

You might wonder, "Why does this matter to me?" Well, when countries don't get along, it can affect many things. It can affect how they help each other. It can affect how they trade things like food or medicine. It can make peace harder to find. It's always better when countries are friends and can talk things out. When countries have good relationships, they can share ideas. They can help each other grow. They can work together to solve big problems in the world. Being kind and respectful is important for everyone, even for countries!

How Can Countries Be Friends Again?

So, what happens next? When friends have a fight, what do you do? You talk about it, right? You try to say sorry, or you try to understand the other person's feelings. Countries do something similar. They might have other people talk for them. Or they might try to find a way to make peace. It takes time, patience, and lots of understanding. It's a bit like fixing a broken toy. You need to be careful and gentle to put it back together. We hope South Africa and Israel can find a way to be friends again soon.

Let's Talk it Out!

This news reminds us that talking is always the best way to solve problems. Even when we are angry or upset, using our words carefully and kindly is very important. Let's all try to be good friends, with our neighbours, our classmates, and even with other countries! It makes the world a much happier place for everyone. Keep shining, super kids!
summary: South Africa and Israel, two countries far apart, both asked each other's special messengers, called envoys, to leave because they had a big disagreement, like friends having a serious fight.
whyMatters: It matters because countries need to be good friends and talk kindly to each other so they can work together, help people, and keep the world peaceful, just like it's good for friends to get along.

title: Mateta 'not in right place' to play against Forest
